Bella started this business more than eight years ago with her own capital; she bought small amounts in the beginning and started increasing with time.

The reason for starting this business was the need to help her partner with the home expenses and their children’s studies. Aware of the good results she is having, she wants to continue with her business, which is her only source of income.

This is Bella’s fourth loan with Kiva and she appreciates the financial help she will receive to continue expanding her business. This time, she is requesting 1500 nuevos soles [PEN] to buy fresh fish. She looks forward to improving her quality of life.

loans.use: to buy fresh fish.

loans.name: Judith

texts.en: Judith is 39 years old and happily married to Rommel. To make a living, Judith owns and operates a food stall. Judith has been engaged in her business for more than three years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities. Now, she is requesting a loan of PHP 10,000 to purchase meat and vegetables to cook and sell. Judith plans to use the additional income generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies.

loans.use: to purchase meat and vegetables to cook and sell

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en: Juliet is 41 years of age; her husband is an OFW at Dubai. They were blessed with four children. She has been managing a retail store in their village for almost 4 years, and with this business she's earning a net income of Php 8,400 a month. She would like to access a loan amounting to Php 15,000 to purchase canned goods, biscuits, noodles, snacks, coffee, sugar, and beverages. She's hoping that her requested loan will be granted so that she will improve and expand her retail store, so that she will earn more income.

loans.use: To purchase canned goods, biscuits, noodles, snacks, coffee, sugar, and beverages

loans.name: Gulzat

texts.ru: Гулзат 41 год, замужем, воспитывает 3 детей. В 2000 году, в поисках дохода для своей семьи, Гулзат начала заниматься животноводством, начав этот бизнес со стартовой суммы 20,000 сом (KGS). В хозяйстве Гулзат на сегодняшний день имеется 2 дойные коровы, 5 голов овец и 1 теленок. Доходы от продажи молочных продуктов составляют примерно 10,000 сом (KGS) в месяц. В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Гулзат обратилась в компанию «Бай –Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 100,000 сом (KGS) на закуп овец и бычков для откорма и перепродажи. Доходы от кредита Гулзат планирует вложить в дальнейшее увеличение хозяйства по средствам увеличения поголовья скота.
texts.en: Gulzat is 41 years old, married and is raising 3 children.  In 2000, while searching for an income for her family, Gulzat started to work with livestock, starting her business with 20,000 KGS.  In her care,  Gulzat has two milk cows, 5 sheep and 1 calf.  The income from the sale of dairy products is around 10,000 KGS a month.  With the goal of further expanding her business, Gulzat has turned to Bai Tushum and Partners for a loan of 100,000 KGS to buy sheep and bulls to fatten and resell.  She plans on reinvesting the income from the loan back into the business buy increasing the number of animals among her livestock.

loans.use: To purchase bulls and sheeps for fattening and resale

loans.name: Zaza

texts.en: Zaza is 41 years old. He lives in the Baghdati district with his wife, retired mother and two children who are going to school. Zaza is working as a security guard at a private company and gets a small monthly income. The family has beehives with bee colonies and they own a small agricultural plot of land where they grow nut trees. They sell the harvested nuts and the honey locally at the markets. Zaza requested a loan for renovating his house. He will purchase building materials and work himself on the renovation. Zaza was planning to sell his beehives with the colonies, which would sufficiently decrease his family income that he could not afford to do it.  With the received credit, Zaza will be able to save the beehives and provide better living conditions for his family.

loans.use: To purchase building materials and renovate his house

loans.name: Gulsara

texts.ru:
Гулсаре 45 лет, замужем, имеет 4 детей. только младший сын учится в школе, старшие дети живут самостоятельно. Гулсара в течении многих лет занимается табачницей,  Гулсара с 1987 года занимается животноводством, начав этот бизнес со стартовой суммы в 5,000 KGS. Благодаря упорному труду Гулсары, в ее хозяйстве на сегодняшний день очень развитое  ежемесячная прибыль составляет около 8,000 сом (KGS) По мимо этого Гульсара занимается изготовлением национальных принадлежностей для невест. 

В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Гулсара обратилась в компанию «Бай –Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 65,000 сом (KGS) на покупку 15 овец. Доходы от кредита Гулсара планирует вложить в дальнейшее увеличение хозяйства и на свадьбу сына.
texts.en:
Gulsara is 45 years old, married, and has 4 children, the youngest of whom is still in school, the oldest are living independently. For many years Gulsara has been engaged in tabacco trade. Since 1987, she has been working in the field of animal husbandry, having started her business with a sum of only 5,000 Kyrgyzstan Som (KGS). Thanks to her hard work, her farm is now very developed and brings in a monthly income of around 8,000 Som. She also makes traditional accessories for brides. 

For the purpose of further developing her business, Gulsara has approached Bai Tushum & Partners for a loan of 65,000 Som to buy 15 sheep. She plans to use the income generated by this loan for the future expansion of her farm and to host her son's wedding.

loans.use: To purchase 15 sheep

loans.name: Emzar

texts.en:
Emzar is 27 years old. He lives in Batumi, West Georgia, with his 19-year-old wife, parents-in-law and sister-in-law, who is going to school. 

Emzar requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. His loan request was rejected all the time because of low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

The only source of income for the family is the small monthly salaries of Emzar and his mother-in-law. He is working at the local market as a miller, and his mother-in-law is working in a retirement house as a cook. Their total income is not enough to feed the five members of the family.

Emzar requested a loan from Credo to start up a family business. His loan request was approved in the framework of a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-start-up credits with soft conditions to the country’s rural poor. The rural poor do not have access to credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income. 

With the received credit, Emzar will purchase packages for packing corn flour. He already has a mill and plans to work from there. As Emzar is already experienced in this field, he hopes his new business will be successful and he will be able to sell a lot of packed corn flour to make a good profit.  

The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start-up loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to purchase packages for packing corn flour.

loans.name: Nazik

texts.en:
Nazik is a 47-year-old woman. She lives in Jigrasheni village, Ninotsminda district with her 53 year old husband and three sons. The only source of income for the family is from agricultural activities and farming. They have five milk cows which are milked every day to make dairy products. The family also owns a plot of land where they grow potatoes, wheat and barley. Harvested products and the dairy products are sold locally at the markets. 

Nazik requested a loan to purchase sheep to make more dairy products. With the profit she plans to develop her farming and buy more sheep. This will increase the income of the family and they will be able to have better living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase sheep to make dairy products.

loans.name: Ilgar

texts.en:
Ilgar is 22 years old. He lives in Ganjala village, Lagodekhi district with his parents. Ilgar requested loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. His loan requests were rejected because of low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

The only source of the income for the family is from agricultural activities. They have a greenhouse where they grow cucumbers and tomatoes seasonally to sell locally at the markets. 

Ilgar requested a loan from Credo to start up a family business. His loan request was approved in the framework of a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to the country's rural poor, who do not have access to credit products, being regarded as “high-risk borrowers” because of low income. 

With the received credit, Ilgar will rent a small commercial space. He will purchase computers and plural techniques. He was working before in a private shop, so he is experienced and knows how to serve people in this field. His shop will be helping all the people who need computer services, as in his village, that’s not accessible for everyone. Ilgar hopes his business will be successful, and he will make a good profit. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start-up loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of Ilgar and his family.

loans.use: To rent a small commercial space and purchase computers and plural techniques.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy more drugs to add to his current stock

loans.name: Batbayar

texts.en:
Mr. Batbayar, 26 years old, sells second-hand mobile phones and their spare parts at his rental stall in the phone mart. He started his business five years ago and attracted quite a numerous customers to his business.  He has divorced his wife and now lives with his mother and his child in the 'ger' district, a part of the city with no central heating and sewerage system, in Ulaanbaatar, capital city of Mongolia. 

Using his first loan, he has repaired the house roof by purchasing boards and metals. Now he is requesting a loan of 1,500,000 MNT to install an electric low pressure cooker in his house. As a result of this electric heater installment, the family will no longer use coal for house heating thus contributing greatly to the efforts against air pollution. Also, it is cost-effective to use the electric heater, and more importantly it is an energy-efficient and environmentally-friendly product. The borrower is a very hardworking individual who deeply cares for his mother and son.

loans.use: To install an electric low pressure heater

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
This is Richard, 23, resident of Intramuros, Philippines. He is still single and he lives with his parents. He helps them in managing their household and he also works to help his family. 

Richard maintains a tricycle business. He owns and drives one unit of tricycle (motor cycle with sidecar) that carries up to four passengers to their destination within the community. He starts working early in the morning and works until late in the evening. There are times when he drives in the late evening, until the wee hours, to have a bigger profit. His regular customers are his neighbors and the local community. His business has a total of four units of tricycle. The other three tricycles are being used by other tricycle drivers, who then remit their daily quota. Richard earns a minimum of PHP 1,200 in his transportation business every day.

To help him continue operations of his business, he is requesting a loan of PHP 20,000. He will be utilizing the loan to buy motorcycle parts for the maintenance of his four tricycle units. He has to maintain his units in good condition in order to have a regular income for the daily needs of his family. 

Richard dreams for the continuous success of his business and hopes to have his own house and lot. Every week, he meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his life and business and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that he studies.

* All Center for Community Transformation Credit Cooperative (CCT) community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for spare parts and the maintenance of his tricycle units.

loans.name: Serason Indah Group

texts.en: The members of the Serason Indah Group live in the center of Bali, near a mountain which keeps their region cool. All the women in this group have husbands who are farmers, and supplement their family's income by raising pigs. After successfully paying off their first loan, the members of this group are applying for a second loan so that they can improve their businesses. Ni Ketut, who leads the group, is coordinating the purchase of new piglets so that each member can get good ones. She is getting three piglets and plans to use the additional money she earns to buy floors for her house.

loans.use: to buy three piglets and feed.

loans.name: Lyra

texts.en:
This is Lyra. Her previous loan was a big help in her business. She was able to buy all the needed products for her grocery store thus generating bigger income. Over five years in the business, she has been able to get the loyalty of her neighborhood. She and her husband work hard to provide income for their everyday expenses.

She would like to apply for another 40,000 PHP loan for her to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add in her inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help cover her family’s daily needs and her children’s education expense. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.


Lyra hopes that her business will grow bigger and she will have a bigger stall. She dreams that her children will finish their studies. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her life and business every week and also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 


* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Vazha

texts.en: Vazha lives in the village of Achkhvistavi in the Kobuleti district. He is married and lives with his wife, Nani, retired parents, and two children who are going to school. The family earns an income from agricultural activities. In particular, they have two cows, a vineyard, and a plot of land where they grow nut trees, citrus, and also maize. They milk the cows to make dairy products and sell them together with the harvested products locally at the markets. With the requested loan, Vazha plans to build a greenhouse where different kinds of vegetables will be grown seasonally. He will purchase wood and polyethylene materials for covering the greenhouse. Using a little part of the loan, he will buy more vegetable seeds. Later, he will grow them, and the harvested product will be sold at the markets. The profit will be used for reinvesting and developing his agricultural business, and Vazha will have more income to provide for his family and create better living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase building materials for building a greenhouse

loans.name: Nimfa

texts.en:
This is Nimfa. Her previous loan was a big help in her business. She was able to buy more materials needed in her sewing business and was able to produce more rugs. She has been in this business for four years now. She is already a widow, and that's why she works very hard to provide income for her family.

She would like to apply for a 19,000 PHP loan to buy additional fabric, thread and other materials needed in her business. Her profits from business will definitely help her to cover her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Nimfa dreams that her business will continue to grow and hopes to have a good life with her family. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for fabric, thread and other materials needed in her business.

loans.name: 402017 Liên Minh _ Hoằng Trường Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Hồng operates a food stall/restaurant selling fish. She is requesting a loan to purchase nets for fishing. Hồng is 25 years old and she is married with two children. She is the leader of a 6-member group, the 402017 solidarity group. Hồng supports her two dependents with her business in Hoang Hoa district, a  rural town in Thanh Hoa province.

This is Hồng's first loan with Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Hồng has been involved in this business for five years. The main hardship that Hồng faces in her business is the lack of capital.

In the future, Hồng hopes to make enough money to provide for her kids, for her family to be healthy and happy, and to be able to buy more supplies and equipment for her business.

loans.use: to purchase nets for fishing.

loans.name: Annalisa

texts.en:
This is Annalisa. She previously accessed a 14,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education, in their personal, household and business expenditures.

She would now like to apply for a 12,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help cover her family’s daily needs and child’s education expense. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Annalisa hopes that her business will get bigger and dreams of having their own house and lot. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and  also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: 24.phú Sơn 1 Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Hường operates a food stall/restaurant selling beverages. She is requesting a loan to purchase candy, biscuits, sugar, and milk for resale. Hường is 56 years old and she is married with one child. Hường is the group leader of the 07.01.24 Phú Sơn solidarity group, which consists of four members. She lives and works in Thanh Hoa city, an urban area in Thanh Hoa province, with no dependents as her child is grown up.

This is Hường's first loan with Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Hường has been involved in this business for eight years. The main hardship that Hường faces in her business is the lack of capital.

In the future, Hường hopes for her business to do well, for her children to find a good job, and for her family to be healthy and happy.

loans.use: to purchase candy, biscuits, sugar, and milk for resale.

loans.name: 04-11-02-Nam Ngạn Group

texts.en:
Yên is applying for a loan to to purchase vegetables, candy, biscuits, sugar, and milk for resale.  She operates a food stall selling vegetables. Yên is 54 years old and she is single with four children.

Yên is the group leader of the 04-11-02-Nam Ngạn solidarity group, which consists of three members. She lives and works in Thanh Hoa city, an urban area in Thanh Hoa province, with no dependents as her children are grown up.

In 2010, Yên joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her  business. Yên has successfully repaid four loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Yên has been involved in this business for more than 10 years. The main hardship that Yên faces in her business is the lack of capital.

In the future, Yên hopes for her family to be healthy and happy, to buy a motorbike, and for her business to do well.

loans.use: to purchase vegetables, candy, biscuits, sugar, and milk for resale.

loans.name: Alison

texts.en: Alison's business is selling vegetables in their village. She has been in this business for ten years and usually earns about a net income of PHP 350 a day. She is now 56 years old and is married with four children. Right now, Alison is asking for a loan in the amount of PHP 5,000 to buy onions, string beans and squash to sell. Alison hopes to have her own stall in the market someday.

loans.use: to buy onions, string beans and squash to sell

loans.name: 01.05.60 Điện Biên Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Lan has a retail business selling clothes. She is requesting a loan to purchase cloth to do tailor-made and clothing repair service. Lan is 49 years old and she is married with two children. Lan is the group leader of the 01.05.60 Điện Biên solidarity group, which consists of five members. She lives and works in Thanh Hoa city, an urban area in Thanh Hoa province, with two dependents

In 2010, Lan joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her  business. Lan has successfully repaid two loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Lan has been involved in this business for six years. The main hardship that Lan faces in her business is the lack of capital.

In the future, Lan hopes for her business to do well, for her children to find a good job, and for her family to be healthy and happy.

loans.use: to purchase cloth to do tailor-made and clothing repair service.

loans.name: Luz

texts.en:
This is Luz. She previously accessed an 16,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education, and in their personal, household, and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 16,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages, and other products to add in her inventory. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from the business will definitely help sustain her family’s daily needs and the children’s education expense. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Luz hopes to expand her business, and dreams of having their own lot and house. It also her desire to give her children a good and quality education. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week, and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy grocery items, toiletries, and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Ana Maria

texts.es: Doña Ana María, una señora muy trabajadora que lucha para salir adelante con su familia y mejorar las condiciones de su hogar, ahora tiene solamente a su cargo a un hijo quien continúa estudiando, su pareja siempre le apoya con sus ingresos para los gastos del hogar. Ana María solicita este nuevo crédito para hacer una división de cuarto necesitando comprar cemento, arena, bloques, hierro para empezar la obra y obtener mejores condiciones en la vivienda, esto la llena de mucha alegría porque cada día va haciéndole mejoras a su casa.
texts.en:
Ana María is a very hardworking woman who strives to get ahead with her family and improve the condition of her home.  Now she's responsible only for one child who is still studying.  Her partner always helps her with his income for the household expenses.

Ana María's requesting this new loan to divide a room.  She needs to buy cement, sand, cinder blocks, and rebar to begin the work and get better conditions at home.

This fills her with happiness because every day she's making improvements to her house.

loans.use: to buy cement, sand, cinder blocks, and rebar

loans.name: Luna Jun

texts.en:
Luna Jun is 27 years old and married with three children.  With one child in school, Luna Jun works very hard to provide for them.

Luna Jun runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 13,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional items to sell like soap, sugar, milk, spices, etc..

Luna Jun has been in this business for four years, and sells a variety of items such as those listed above. 

In the future, Luna Jun would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell like soap, sugar, milk, spices, etc. in her general store.

loans.name: Medalla Milagrosa Group

texts.es:
El grupo Medalla Milagrosa está en el 9º ciclo. Están haciendo la encuesta de eliminación de pobreza, donde desde este año  ninguna integrante  se encuentra por debajo de la línea de pobreza, ya que todas ellas se han esforzado y gracias al trabajo que han hecho están donde están.
La Sra. Rosa es modista y tiene un taller de costuras, el crédito lo solicita para la compra de hilos y telas para poder ofrecer mejores precios a sus clientas, en su última encuesta se encontraba fuera de la línea de la pobreza, pero de igual manera sigue muy entusiasmada invirtiendo el dinero del préstamo que realiza dentro del comité.
Agradece por la oportunidad que está recibiendo ya que le será de muy útil, no solo a ella, sino también a su familia.
texts.en:
The group Medalla Milagrosa [Miraculous Medallion] is in its 9th cycle. They took part in a “poverty elimination” survey, and none of the members was found to live below the poverty line, thanks to their effort. They have come this far thanks to the work they have done.

Mrs. Rosa is a tailor and has a tailoring workshop. She is requesting a loan to buy threads and fabrics in order to offer better prices to her customers. In the last survey she took, she was found to be above the poverty line, but she feels anyhow enthusiastic investing the money from the loan she received through the group.

Rosa appreciates this opportunity because it will be useful, not only for her, but also for her family.

loans.use: to buy threads and fabrics.

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
María, de 65 años es una mujer valiente y emprendedora.  Tuvo 07 hijos a quienes brindó educación y crianza hasta que ellos pudieron ser independientes.  Vive en su casa propia a lado de su esposo Arturo quien le brinda  las fuerzas para seguir adelante.El trabajo de María consiste en la venta de ropas de segunda mano de toda variedad para damas, caballeros y niños . Toda su mercadería la compra en el centro comercial de  su ciudad  y lo lleva a vender por las zonas y distritos alejados. 
Se inició en ésta actividad por la idea e iniciativa de su esposo hace más de 05 años actualmente le va muy bien aunque su trabajo a veces le resulta un poco pesado por los viajes que realiza y  porque tiene que cargar a veces su mercadería sola,  pero sabe que debe que esforzarse al máximo para poder tener mejores ganancias ,a  pesar de que vende mucho, le gustaría  tener mayores ganancias y vender en mayor volumen , por eso desea seguir trabajando y  hacer crecer su negocio.Este es el crédito número 3 con Kiva, por tanto espera contar con su colaboración para continuar con sus objetivos, por su parte se compromete a cumplir con sus cuotas de manera puntual.En está oportunidad solicitara S/. 1500 soles para la compra de ropas de segunda mano en mayor cantidad buscando precios bajos para sus compras en volumen y de esa manera podrá obtener mayores ganancias.
texts.en:
Maria is 65 years old and a very courageous and entrepreneurial woman.  She had seven children whom she raised and to whom she has provided an education so that they could become independent.  She lives in a home of her own, along with her husband, Arturo who provides her the strength to move forward.  Maria’s work consists of selling second hand clothing for women, men, and children.  She buys all of her merchandise in the mall in town and takes it to the surrounding zones and districts.

She began doing this because of her husband’s idea and initiative more than five years ago.  Things have been going well with her work although her work is sometimes a bit difficult because of the trips she makes and because she has to carry her merchandise herself but she knows that she has to put forth the maximum effort in order to be able to maximize her earnings.  Even though she makes many sales, she would like to maximize her earnings and sell in large volume, so she wants to keep working and grow her business.  This will be her third loan through Kiva and she hopes to be able to count on your support so that she can continue her objectives.  She is committed to making her payments on time.  She is asking for 1,500 PEN in order to buy second hand clothing in quantity.  She is looking for low prices by buying in volume and in this way she can increase her income.

loans.use: to buy clothing.

loans.name: Berawan Salak Permai Group

texts.en:
Ni Kadek works raising pigs. Her husband helps her by providing traditional pig feed, such as banana leaf, every day from his garden. Ni Kadek is a member of the Berawan Salak Permai loan group, which is requesting a new loan of 15,000,000 IDR. Each member will receive 1,500,000 IDR.  

Ni Kadek will use her portion of this group loan to purchase two superior piglets for fattening along with pig feed. To reduce her cost, Ni Kadek combines her traditional feed with mixture feed. She hopes that within the next five months her pigs will grow fast so she can sell them at a high price. In the future, Ni Kadek hopes to save money and renovate her kitchen.

loans.use: to buy piglets and feed

loans.name: Rose Ann

texts.en:
Rose Ann works hard to support her family. She is married, and has a buying and selling rice business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for two years.

Rose Ann requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional sacks of rice to sell.

In the future, Rose Ann would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional sacks of rice to sell.

loans.name: Alfredo

texts.en:
Alfredo is 47 years old and married with six children. For the past six years, he has been raising hogs in Amulung. Alfredo earns about 2,000 PHP for each hog disposed. 

Alfredo is requesting a 7,000 PHP loan to buy feed and vaccines to sustain his business. In the future, he hopes to keep raising healthy hogs and generate good sales to improve his income.

loans.use: to buy feed and vaccines to sustain his business

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
This is Tessie. Her previous loan was a big help in her business. She was able to buy more products for her variety store, thus generating more income. She has been in this business for four years now. As a widow, she works hard to provide income for her everyday needs.

She would like to apply for another PHP 22,000 loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages, and other products to add to her current inventory. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Tessie dreams to expand her business and have more businesses. Every week, she meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business and also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All Center for Community Transformation Credit Cooperative (CCT) community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries, and beverages, needed in her business.

loans.name: Julia

texts.es: Julia, de 63 años de edad, está casada con Máximo quien es comerciante y padre de sus hijos quienes ya son mayores e independientes. Juntos habitan cómodamente su casa propia.La actividad que realiza Julia es la comercialización de abarrotes, artículos de librería, medicamentos y otros, para esto abrió una pequeña tienda en su hogar, desde ahí atiende las necesidades de sus vecinos, quienes son sus principales clientes.Se inició hace más de 08 años en este negocio logrando hacerse muy conocida .Antes de empezar con su negocio tenía dificultades económicas ya que los alimentos suben  de precios constantemente y los ingresos de su esposo no les alcanzaban para cubrir todos sus gastos, por eso quiso apoyarlo generándose sus propios ingresos económicos.Este es el préstamo número 04 con Kiva , por tanto espera contar con su apoyo financiero para cumplir con sus objetivos laborales y de la misma forma se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas de manera puntual.En esta oportunidad solicitará S/. 1000 nuevos soles para la compra de abarrotes en general como arroz, azúcar, aceites, entre otros.
texts.en:
Julia, 63, is married to Máximo, a merchant and the father of her children, who are already adults and independent.  They live together comfortably in their own house.

Julia's job is selling groceries, bookstore items, medicine, and other products.  She opened a small store in her house, where she tends to the needs of her neighbors, who are her main customers.  She started in this business more than eight years ago and managed to become very well known.

Before opening her business she had financial problems because food prices are constantly going up and her husband's income wasn't enough to cover all their expenses, so she wanted to help him by generating her own income.

This is her fourth loan with Kiva.  She hopes to have your financial support to achieve her work goals, and she pledges to make her payments punctually.

Currently she's going to request 1000 nuevos soles [PEN] to buy a variety of groceries, including rice, sugar, and oil.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar, milk, and other groceries

loans.name: 3.8.259.15.thiệu Toán Group

texts.en: Mrs. Thảo works in agriculture, raising poultry and cattle. She is applying for a loan to purchase baby poultry to raise and sell. Thảo is 18 years old. She is married and has no children. Thảo is the group leader of the 3.8.259.15.Thiệu Toán solidarity group, which consists of three members. Thao’s business is in Thieu Toan, a rural town in Thieu Hoa district. This is Thảo’s first loan from Thanh Hoa Fund of Poor Women. Thảo has been in this business for a year. One of the most critical business difficulties that concerns her is the lack of capital. With her business profits, Thảo hopes for her business to do well, and that she can buy land of her own and be able to buy more supplies and equipment for her business.

loans.use: to purchase baby poultry to raise and sell.

loans.name: 3.8.260.16.thiệu Toán Group

texts.en: Mrs. Bình works in agriculture, raising poultry and cattle. She is applying for a loan to purchase baby poultry to raise and sell. Bình is 42 years old. She is married and has three children. Bình is the group leader of the 3.8.260.16.Thiệu Toán solidarity group, which consists of four members. Binh supports her children with her business in Thieu Toan Town, a rural area in Thieu Hoa district. This is Bình’s first loan from Thanh Hoa Fund of Poor Women. Bình has been in this business for a year. One of the most critical business difficulties that concerns her is the lack of capital. With her business profits, Bình hopes for her business to do well, and that she can buy land of her own and be able to buy more supplies and equipment for her business.

loans.use: to purchase baby poultry to raise and sell.

loans.name: 04-05-03-Nam Ngạn Group

texts.en: Mrs. Hoa has a retail business selling dry food. She is requesting a loan to buy more sugar, milk, candy and biscuits to sell to her customers. She is 42 years old, married and the mother of two children. She also leads a three-person loan group called 04-05-03-Nam Ngạn Solidarity, and lives and works in Thanh Hoa city, a urban area in Thanh Hoa province. This is her first loan request from the Thanh Hoa Fund of Poor Women. She has been involved in her current line of work for 10 years and in that time, her main challenge has been a lack of capital. Hoa plans to use the profit she earns from her business to keep her family healthy and happy, build a new house, and keep her business doing well.

loans.use: to buy sugar, milk, candy and biscuits to sell.

loans.name: Nida

texts.en: Nida works hard to support her family. She is married and has a tailoring business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 3 years now. She requested a PHP 13,000 loan through NWTF to buy materials like needles, fabric, textiles, etc. for her business. In the future, Nida would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy materials like needles, fabric, textiles, etc. for her business.

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
As a married parent of three children, Mary Jane works hard to support her family. She has a buy-and-sell dried fish business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from food vending. She is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF to purchase additional boxes of dried fish to sell.

Mary Jane has been sustaining her business activities through her past 4 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional boxes of dried fish to sell.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy is 34 years old,  and sells dry goods such as combs, wall clocks, and needles. With more than six years managing her business, she has found it contributes a convenient lifestyle for her family, and she wants to continue this good lifestyle with the help of her business.  

She is requesting a loan of PHP 20,000 to buy additional goods to offer such as plastic wares, toothbrushes, mothballs, and detergent to add stock to her business. 

She hopes it will increase her income and improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to buy additional goods to sell such as plastic wares, toothbrushes, mothballs, and detergent.

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna works hard to support her family. Edna is married and has a general store business in the Philippines.

Edna requested a 12,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like shampoo, canned goods, soap, milk, sugar, noodles, etc.

Edna has been in this business for seven years now, and also earns additional income from farming rice.

In the future, Edna would like to build and expand her business to secure the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like shampoo, canned goods, soap, milk, sugar, noodles, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more animal feeds, vaccines, medicines and vitamins to sell.

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann is 25 years old, and her family happily resides in Barangay Estrella.

Mary Ann has been in the direct selling business for three years. She is now generating a monthly net income of PHP 4,000. She is glad that, through patience, she was able to improve her small enterprise. 

She wanted to borrow at least PHP 12,000 to buy more products such as lotion, deodorant, powder, and cologne to sell. With this amount, she can sell more products, and hopefully save some of her income for her family.

loans.use: to buy more products such as lotion, deodorant, powder, and cologne to sell.

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
This is Alma, 54, a resident of Payatas, Philippines. She is married to Teddie, a driver, and they have children. She and her husband manage their household while operating the business. She works hard to continually provide income for their every-day expenses. Alma operates a variety store in the Philippines. A variety store is a retail store that sells inexpensive items, often with a single price for all items in the store. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, five pesos worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 from her sales every day. She is applying for a PHP 30,000 loan to help her continue operating her business. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. Alma dreams of expanding her business and of giving her children a good, quality, education. She meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week, where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies. 

All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Satya Laksana Group

texts.en: The Satya Laksana Group continues borrowing to grow their businesses. The members decided to use the loan exclusively to buy superior piglets at the same price per pig, to make better profits by selling them together later, to a big buyer. Ni Ketut purchased three superior piglets.  To reduce costs, she has combined superior feed with a traditional feed. Ni Ketut and her husband are really grateful for the loans they have had. They hope their profits will be higher than before.

loans.use: to purchase superior piglets and feed.

loans.name: Vicky

texts.en:
Vicky is a business-minded woman who sells slippers and shoes. She has been working so hard to provide for the educational needs of her child. She’s been operating her business for ten months. She usually earns a net income of almost PHP 10,000  per month; she saves this for daily consumption and emergency purposes. 

Despite the difficulty in selling slippers and shoes due to competitors, she works hard to acquire loyal customers in order to provide for the needs of her family. 

She is requesting a loan of PHP 30,000 to buy more slippers and shoes to sell. 

She hopes that she can roll the profits from her loan into improving their living conditions, as well as to advance her business.

loans.use: to buy more slippers and shoes to sell.

loans.name: Tunas Mekar Asih Group

texts.en:
Ni Ketut and the members of Tunas Mekar Asih are really thankful because they still have trust to receive their eighth loan. They will get the same loan size with 11 members. The loan will be used to increase the members' pig businesses.

Ni Ketut has a 9-year-old daughter, and she is still in the third year of elementary school. Her husband works as a farmer. Beside being a pig breeder, Ni Ketut also has a small kiosk in front of her house. Every day, after she finishes preparing the needs of her family, she will open the small kiosk until 6:00 pm. 

Now she has two sows, and one of them already gave birth to 10 healthy piglets last week. The loan received will be used to purchase superior feed and renovate the cage. She hopes the piglets can grow fast, and she plans to sell them after two months.

loans.use: to purchase superior feed and renovate the cage.

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en: Julieta is married and has seven children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Julieta is 52 years old, and three of her children are in school. Julieta has a business buying and selling vegetables in the Philippines. She has applied for a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional vegetables to sell. Julieta has been in this business for ten years. In the future, Julieta would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
This is Erlinda. Her previous loan was a big help in her business. She was able to buy all the products needed for her store. She has been in this business for six years, and it continues to grow. She and her husband work hard to provide income for their everyday needs.

She would like to apply for another 40,000 PHP loan to purchase additional vegetables and different cooking products and supplies for her business. Her profits from the business will definitely help her sustain her daily needs, and the educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Erlinda hopes to expand her business and have an additional stall. She dreams of giving her children a good and quality education. Every week, she meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business, and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional vegetables and cooking products to sell at her stall.

loans.name: Franklin

texts.en: Franklin lives in Port-a-Piment, Haiti, an area with erratic access to electricity. He has a degree in accounting and he works as a taxi driver of motorcycle. One of the reasons he wants to sell cookstoves is because he doesn’t like seeing people cut down trees to produce charcoal. EarthSpark efficient cookstoves can help minimize the effects of charcoal on the environment by reducing carbon emissions and deforestation. He has started to sell clean energy products with EarthSpark. He used this “business in a bag” to launch a clean energy entrepreneurship with EarthSpark. He sold out of his products so quickly that he has paid off his loan and is now coming back to us for another loan. This time, he would like to double his business and is asking for 730 USD. With this money, he will continue to sell solar desk lamps and efficient stoves. With his first Kiva loan, Franklin was set up with a “Business in a Bag”, a kit containing a personalized mix of small-scale clean energy products, marketing materials and training on energy literacy, SMS tracking of sales, and basic business skills.

loans.use: to purchase stock for a clean energy business.

loans.name: Altise

texts.en: Altise is an EarthSpark clean energy entrepreneur selling Lanp Enèji Pwòp solar light bulbs on a rent-to-own basis. She lives in Chardonnieres, Haiti about a 6 hours’ drive from Port-au-Prince in an area without access to electricity. She first started selling EarthSpark products after being a customer. She had bought a Lanp Enèji Pwòp to replace her sooty kerosene stove. After noticing that her son’s eyes didn’t water while studying with a Lanp Enèji Pwòp the way they had under a kerosene lamp, she decided she wanted to spread the word within her community. She currently has 30 customers renting out Lanp Enèji Pwòp and she has started to sell clean energy products with EarthSpark. She used this “business in a bag” to launch a clean energy entrepreneurship with EarthSpark. She sold out of her products so quickly that she has paid off her loan and is now coming back to us for another loan. This time, she would like to double her business and is asking for 630 USD. With this money, she will continue to sell solar desk lamps and efficient stoves. With her first Kiva loan, Altise was set up with a “Business in a Bag”, a kit containing a personalized mix of small-scale clean energy products, marketing materials and training on energy literacy, SMS tracking of sales, and basic business skills.

loans.use: to purchase stock for a clean energy business.

loans.name: Emma

texts.en: Farming is Emma's business. She is 35 years old. She is happily married to Jovent who is also engaged in the farming business. The couple usually plants bananas and corn in their village. They are both hard workers because they want to give their two children a better life. As of now, Emma needs additional capital. In this regard, she is asking for a loan in the amount of PHP 25,000 to buy fertilizers and insecticides for their agricultural business. She hopes to grow her business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and insecticides for her agricultural business.

loans.name: Ioseb

texts.en:
Ioseb is 49 years old. He is married and lives with his wife, 3 children (5, 14 and 16 years old) and his mother in the Terjola District. His mother is provided with a retirement pension. Ioseb requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. His loan request was rejected all the time, because of low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

The only source of income for the family is from their agricultural business. They have a pig, a calf and two milk cows, whose milk is used in cheese production.  They also have 0.8 hectares of agricultural land and a vineyard with 800 samples of grapevines. They harvest grapes and make wine for selling. The income is hardly enough for food for the family. According to Credo estimations the family belongs to the subsistence poor category. 

Ioseb requested a loan from Credo to start up a family business. His loan request was approved within the framework of a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages the provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to country rural poor who do not have access to credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income. With the received credit Ioseb will build a shed for chicks. After the shed is built he will be able to purchase chicks and raise them for selling, and thereby increase the income of the family. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva Start-up loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to build a shed for chicks, and then buy chicks and raise them for selling.

loans.name: Selnys

texts.en: Selnys lives in Felix, a small village about few kilometers from Port-Salut in an area without access to electricity. He is married and has four children with his wife who is a seamstress; three of them are in school. Selnys is a cabinetmaker, painter and retailer of pharmaceuticals products in different localities of the south department of Haiti for over 15 years. He has recently decided to start selling EarthSpark clean energy products to expand his current business. With a Kiva loan, Selnys will be set up with a “Business in a Bag”, a kit containing a personalized mix of small-scale clean energy products, marketing materials and training on energy literacy, SMS tracking of sales, and basic business skills.  Selnys would like to sell solar energy desk lamps with mobile phone charging capability. He wants to sell clean energy products because he likes business and the local population really likes EarthSpark products.

loans.use: to purchase stock for a clean energy business.

loans.name: Efigemia

texts.en:
As the married parent of three children, Efigemia works hard to support her family.

She has a buying and selling charcoal business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from a general store, and mobile prepaid load (selling cell phone time). Efigemia is borrowing PHP 17,000 through NWTF to purchase additional sacks of charcoal to sell.

Efigemia has sustained her business activities through her past nine loans from NWTF.  She hopes her hard work will help attain her dream to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Oscar

texts.es:
El señor Oscar tiene 46 años, está casado con la señora Isidora ambos nacidos en la ciudad de Caacupé, tienen 3 hijos, quienes están con ellos, y que también los ayudan en su negocio familiar.
El señor Oscar se dedica a la Heladería y a la venta de empanadas y tiene su local de ventas en su casa, también tiene varios vendedores que recorren con sus carritos para helados que venden en forma ambulante.
Solicita el crédito para remodelar su local de ventas y para la elaboración de las empanadas. Agradece por la ayuda y la oportunidad que está recibiendo, ya que le será muy útil para poder seguir trabajando.
texts.en:
Oscar, 46, is married to Isidora.  Both of them were born in the city of Caacupé.  They have three children who live with them and also help them in their family business.

Oscar makes a living with an ice cream shop and selling empanadas.  His store is in his house.  He also has several vendors who go through the streets selling on foot with their ice cream carts.

He's requesting the loan to remodel his store and to make empanadas.

He's grateful for the help and for this opportunity, which will be very useful for him to continue working.

loans.use: to expand his space and to buy ingredients for empanadas

loans.name: Paulino

texts.en:
Paulino is 32 years old and still single. His ambition in life is to become successful and financially stable someday. He plans to build his own house before he settles down. To generate income, he is engaged in selling snack foods on the street, sidewalks and on the school campus on school days. 

He aims to continue and improve the business but he doesn't have enough capital. In this regard, he is asking for a loan of PHP10,000 to buy fish balls, kikiam (ground pork and vegetables wrapped in bean curd sheets), balut (boiled fertilized duck embryo), hot dogs and needed seasonings. Through his patience and hard work, he believes that he will improve the business through this financial assistance.

loans.use: to buy fish balls, kikiam, balut, hot dogs and seasonings.

loans.name: Clemencia

texts.en:
Clemencia runs a tailoring business and made good use of a previous loan to buy the materials she needs to do her work. She has been in this line of work for seven years, and shares her responsibilities with her husband. She is requesting a new loan for PHP 20,000 to buy additional supplies such as fabric, cloth and thread. The profits she earns from this loan will help her meet her daily needs. She is grateful for the support she receives from Kiva lenders. Clemencia meets  with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week; this is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from her religion.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who gather to study religion, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy supplies for a tailoring business.

loans.name: Zulma

texts.es:
La señora Zulma tiene 44 años, su principal fuente de ingreso es a través de la venta de muebles que vende por pedido, actualmente está viviendo por las compañías de la ciudad de Itá.
Hace más de 15 años que se dedica a las ventas, tiene una clientela bien formada que siempre les hace pedidos y gracias a esto está saliendo adelante.
Solicita el préstamo para la compra de muebles, ya que tiene una oferta y con ello podrá tener mayores ganancias y seguir ayudando a su familia. Agradece por la oportunidad que está recibiendo, ya que no solo ella será beneficiada con esto, sino también su familia.
texts.en:
Zulma is 44 years old and her main source of income is selling furniture to order.  She is currently living near the city of Itá.  Zulma has been selling for more than 15 years and has a well-established group of customers who place orders with her.  As a result, she is managing to make progress.

Zulma is requesting this loan to buy furniture as she has a special offer which will enable her to make more profits and continue helping her family.  She is grateful for the opportunity that she is receiving as it will not only benefit her but also her family.

loans.use: to buy furniture to sell

loans.name: Charina

texts.en:
Charina works hard to support her family. She is married and has a general store business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 12 years. 

She requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more items like shampoo, body lotion, plasticware and other groceries. In the future, Charina would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more items like shampoo, body lotion, plasticware and other groceries.

loans.name: Hardilita

texts.en:
Hardilita is 36 years old and married with five children, all of whom are currently in school. Hardilita is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a food vending business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 4 years. She earns more income from direct selling Avon products.

She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her food vending business. She is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF to buy ingredients for her business. 

Hardilita has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to school in the future.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business.

loans.name: Ayan

texts.en:
Ayan is 27 years old and married with two children currently in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. She has a motorcycle transport business in the Philippines and has been in this business for 5 years. 

She requested a PHP 20,500 loan amount through NWTF to purchase spare parts for the maintenance of her motorcycle. In the future, Ayan would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts for the maintenance of her motorcycle.

loans.name: Jovina

texts.en:
Jovina is 41 years old and married with six children. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to purchase items to sell like canned goods, soap, spices, snack foods, etc. 

She has been running the general store for 10 years and also earns an income from raising pigs and from a buy-and-sell dried fish business. Jovina has borrowed and paid 7 loans from NWTF before this loan. She aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase items to sell like canned goods, soap, spices, snack foods, etc.

loans.name: Eka

texts.en:
Eka is 38 years old. She is married and lives with her husband, son and cousin. Her cousin is provided with a retirement pension. Eka requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for family business start-up, but without any success. Her loan request was rejected all the time, because of low income and family’s poor living conditions. 

The only source of the income for the family is from the agricultural business. In particular, they have two pigs and sell piglets seasonally. They also have three milking cows, whose milk is used in cheese production.  In addition, they have 0.9 hectare agricultural land and vineyard with 1800 wine trees. They harvest grapes and make wine and vodka to sell. It is hardly enough food for the family. According to Credo estimations the family belongs to the subsistence poor category. 

Eka requested a loan from Credo to start-up a family business. Her loan request was approved in the frames of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to the country's rural poor who do not have access to credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income. With the received credit Eka will build a shed for chicks. After the shed is built she will be able to purchase chicks, raise them to sell, and increase the income of the family. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva Start-up loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to build a shed, purchase chicks, and raise them for selling

loans.name: Jenalin

texts.en:
Jenalin is 32 years old and married with eight children. All of her children are in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. 

Jenalin has a fish vending business in the Philippines. Jenalin requested a PHP 19000 loan amount through NWTF to buy more fish to sell.

Jenalin has been in this business for ten years. In the future, Jenalin would like to build and expand her business so she continue to send her children to school.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a display case and some beauty products

loans.name: Fernando De Jesús

texts.es:
Fernando de 32 años de edad es un campesino, emprendedor y con muchos sueños que desea convertir en realidad. Desde hace 20 años reside en una vereda del municipio de Sonsón, Colombia. Se dedica a la comercialización de frutas y hortalizas, las  cuales compra a los campesinos de la región y la distribuye en la plaza de mercado de su localidad. Labora todos los días de 5 de la mañana a 5 de la tarde y en conjunto con su esposa que le colabora después de realizar los destinos de casa. 
Su mayor sueño es poder brindarle a su hijo menor de edad, mejores condiciones de vida y una buena educación. Espera que con la rentabilidad de su negocio pueda ahorrar y adquirir vivienda propia.
Con el propósito de lograr sus sueños, se encuentra solicitando un crédito que invertirá en la compra de frutas y hortalizas para mejorar sus ventas e ingresos
texts.en:
32-year-old Fernando is an entrepreneur who has a lot of dreams he would like to fulfill.  He has been living in the town of Sonsón, Colombia, for the past 20 years.  His business is selling fruit and vegetables which he buys from local farmers and distributes in the market square in his town.  He works every day, from 5.00am to 5.00pm.  His wife works alongside him after she has finished the household chores. 

Fernando's biggest dream is to provide his young son with better living conditions and a good education.  He hopes that he will be able to use the profits from his business to save up and buy his own home.

With the aim of fulfilling his dreams, Fernando is requesting a loan to invest in buying fruit and vegetables so that he can improve his sales and income.

loans.use: to buy fruit and vegetables

loans.name: Niza

texts.en:
Niza is 46 years old and married with six children, three of whom are in school. Niza works very hard to provide for them.

Niza runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 20000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like shampoo, toothpaste, biscuits, soft drinks, bread, etc.

Niza has been in this business for 20 years.

In the future Niza would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy items to sell such as shampoo, toothpaste, biscuits, soft drinks, bread, etc.

loans.name: 3.8.248.13.thiệu Toán Group

texts.en:
Hằng is 23 years old and married with two children. She works farming poultry and cattle and lives and works in Thieu Toan, a rural town. Hằng is the group leader of the 3.8.248.13.Thiệu Toán solidarity group, which consists of four members. She joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her business and has successfully repaid two previous loans. Hằng's most critical business difficulty is the lack of capital.

Hằng is requesting a loan to purchase baby poultry to raise and sell. In the future, she hopes that her business will do well and that she will make enough money to provide for her kids and to be able to buy more supplies and equipment for her business.

loans.use: to purchase baby poultry to raise and sell

loans.name: Janeth

texts.en:
Janeth is 44 years old, married, and has four children, three of whom attend school.  She is in the agricultural business of pig fattening in the Philippines, which she has been doing for four years. 

Janeth is requesting her fifth loan from NWTF for 12,000 PHP, which she will use to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.  She would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Mely

texts.en:
Mely is 62 years old. At her age, Mely still works in a retailing business to earn income. From this business, she is able to earn about 500 PHP (Philippines pesos) a day. She is grateful that her income allows her to help sustain the daily needs of her family. She dreams of lifting her family from poverty, which is why she works hard at her retailing business. 

She is requesting a loan of PHP 28,000 to buy grocery items for her sari-sari store. Mely also hopes to grow her business to secure her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy grocery items for her sari-sari (variety) store.

loans.name: Dios Padre Group

texts.es:
El grupo se llama Dios Padre en homenaje a la capilla que lleva el mismo nombre , las integrantes están en su ciclo número 2 del programa de comité de mujeres. Ellas están haciendo la encuesta de eliminación de pobreza donde todas se están esforzando por salir y ayudar a sus familias.
Edih, se encuentra mejorando su situación de pobreza, pero igualmente está consciente de que este trabajo y esfuerzo que está haciendo debe ser continuo y permanente para lograr un éxito. Ella se dedica a la venta de prendas de todo tipo, como ser camisas, remeras, pantalones y demás. Ella es muy trabajadora y emprendedora y lucha por seguir trabajando.
Solicita el crédito para la compra de prendas de todo tipo, y con eso poder seguir trabajando y cumpliendo con el pedido de sus clientes.
texts.en:
The group is called “God the Father” in homage to the chapel with the same name.  The members are in their second cycle in the program of the women’s committee.  They are completing the elimination of poverty survey where they are all making an effort to help their families.

Edih is improving her poverty situation but she is also aware that this work and effort she is making must be continuous and permanent in order to achieve success.  She sells clothing of all types, such as shirts, t-shirts, pants, and other things.  She is a very hard and enterprising worker and struggles to continue working.

She is asking for this loan so that she can buy clothing of all types and be able to continue working and keeping up with her customers’ requests.

loans.use: to buy clothing.

loans.name: Tomasia

texts.en: Tomasia is 30 years old, and she is married. She has a second-hand clothes shop, to generate income for her family. She has been thinking about how to run a big business, but she does not have enough working capital. She feels better, having applied for her first loan. She will use this loan to buy some additional supplies to keep in her store, such as pants, long pants, trunks, long sleeved clothes, and short sleeved clothes. She is happy with TRM (Tuba Rai Metin), which offers loans to poor people.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her second-hand clothes shop

loans.name: Hervie

texts.en:
Hervie works hard to support her family. Hervie is married and has a general store business in the Philippines.

Hervie requested a 27,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like shampoo, canned goods, eggs, noodles, snack foods, etc.

Hervie has been in this business for three years now.

In the future, Hervie would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like shampoo, canned goods, eggs, noodles, snack foods, etc.

loans.name: Jerren

texts.en:
Jerren works hard to support her family. Jerren is married and has an Internet cafe business in the Philippines.

Jerren requested a 13,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc., to buy spare parts for the maintenance of her computers.

Jerren has been in this business for three years now.

Jerren would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy spare parts for the maintenance of her computers.

loans.name: 3.8.249.10.thiệu Toán Group

texts.en:
Mẫn is 60 years old and married with two adult children. She works raising marine aquaculture in Thieu Toan, a rural town. Mẫn joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women in 2009 to improve her business and has successfully repaid four previous loans. Mẫn's most critical business difficulty is the lack of capital. She is the group leader of the 3.8.249.10.Thiệu Toán solidarity group, which consists of four members. 

Mẫn is requesting a loan to purchase baby fish to raise and sell. In the future, she hopes that her business will do well and that she will be able to remodel her house and buy more supplies and equipment for her business.

loans.use: to purchase baby fish to raise and sell

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene is a married woman with three children, one of whom is in school. She is 49 years old, and a very hard-working entrepreneur.

Irene has a charcoal-selling business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 15 years. She requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF, to purchase more charcoal to resell. She would like to save money, to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal to resell

loans.name: Emerly

texts.en:
Emerly is 40 years old, married, and has four school-age children. Due to the high cost of school fees and commodities, she aimed to improve her small variety store, to generate sufficient income. She and her husband aimed to educate their children and give them a bright future.

To improve the business, she is asking for additional capital of PHP 10,000 to buy more stock to resell, of items like canned goods, snack foods, beverages, seasonings, soft drinks, soaps and mineral water. She believes that someday, she will be able to make more improvements in the business as she continues to work hard and strive for it.

loans.use: to buy more stock to sell, of items like canned goods, snack foods, beverages, seasonings, soft drinks, soaps and mineral water

loans.name: Catalina

texts.en:
Catalina is a 60-year-old married mother of six grown-up children from Getafe, Bohol. She is engaged in selling firewood in the market. She is also a fish vendor.
Catalina is asking for a loan to buy piglets to raise and additional fish to sell. With this loan, she will be able to improve her business and augment her income.
in the future, Catalina hopes of making her business a success.

loans.use: to buy piglets to raise and additional fish to sell

loans.name: Nelia

texts.en:
Nelia is 58 years old and married with six children. She works very hard to provide for them.

Nelia runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 14000 loan through NWTF to purchase spices, eggs, noodles, soap, canned goods, etc. to sell in her store.

Nelia has been in this business for five years.

In the future, Nelia would like to build and expand her business to secure the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to purchase spices, eggs, noodles, soap, canned goods, etc. for her general store.

loans.name: Constancia

texts.en:
Constancia is a 54-year-old married mother of five children from Talibon, Bohol. She has been engaged in a hog-raising business for more than three years now. Her husband works as a fisherman.
Constancia is asking for a loan to buy feed for the pigs and to pay the school fees of her children. In the future, Constancia hopes to make her business a success. Moreover, she wants to save money for the schooling of her children.

loans.use: to buy feed for the pigs and pay the school fees of her children

loans.name: Justina

texts.en:
Justina is 57 years old, mariied and has four children.

Justina is in the agricultural business, buying and selling livestock in the Philippines. Justina requested a PHP 22000 loan through NWTF to buy additional livestock to sell.

Justina has been in this business for eight years now, and has borrowed 10 times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

Justina would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional livestock to sell

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet works hard to support her family. She is married, and has had a motorcycle transport business in the Philippines for 18 years. 

Janet requested a PHP 18,000 loan through NWTF to buy spare parts for her motorcycle transport business.

In the future, Janet would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy spare parts for her motorcycle transport business.

loans.name: Makvala

texts.en:
Makvala is 54 years old. She is married and lives with her husband and 33-year-old daughter, in Kaspi district. Makvala requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. Her loan request was rejected each time, because of low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

The only source of income for the family is the monthly income of her husband and daughter. Her husband works as a laborer in a cement factory, and her daughter is a nurse at the local hospital. Their income is hardly enough to provide food for the family. According to Credo estimations the family belongs to the subsistence poor category. 

Makvala requested a loan from Credo to start up a family business. Her loan request was approved, in the frame of a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The Start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and restart-up credits with soft conditions, to the country's rural poor people, who do not have access to regular credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income. With the received credit, Makvala will trade in clothing. She plans to purchase clothing at wholesale prices and then resell the garments at higher prices, among her fellow villagers. This will increase the income of the family.  The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva Start-up loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to purchase a start-up inventory of clothing to resell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay for motorcycle maintenance (gasoline, motor oil, motor parts )

loans.name: Luciana

texts.en:
Luciana is married and a hardworking entrepreneur who has a general store business in the Philippines. She successfully repaid her previous loan, and is now requesting a new loan to further build her general store.

She is borrowing PHP 30,000 through NWTF to purchase more groceries to sell at her store.

NWTF is re-listing Luciana's business profile again in support of her efforts to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell at her store.

loans.name: Nimfa

texts.en:
Nimfa is 48 years old and married with three children, one of whom is in school.  She works very hard to provide for them.

Nimfa runs a general store in the Philippines, and requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to buy stock to sell like soap, coffee, sugar, soft drinks, bread, etc.. She has been in this business for five years.

In the future, Nimfa would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy stock to sell like soap, coffee, sugar, soft drinks, bread, etc. in her general store.

loans.name: Pachamama Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “PACHAMAMA”  iniciará el tercer ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de German Busch, está compuesta por ocho integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Janet es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: venta y costura de deportivos, venta de gelatinas, venta de guantes, venta y producción de chompas, venta de refrescos, tienda de barrio, producción de chompas, producción y venta de pan.

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Janet es integrante, ella indica que hace tres ciclos que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por invitación de una amiga que es socia de la institución. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de venta de carteras; da a conocer que este negocio lo aprendió de su amiga, que vendía en los mercados este producto.
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de carteras) que adquirirá de las vendedoras mayoristas de la ciudad de La Paz y posteriormente lo comercializará de forma ambulante en las ferias de la Ciudad de El alto. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para mantener en lo posible a su hogar pues ella vive en concubinato y tiene cinco hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta le gusta las capacitaciones en salud y crédito.
texts.en:
The "Pachamama" communal bank will begin its third cycle with Pro Mujer as part of the German Busch regional office. The group is made up of eight members and is governed by a board of directors, of which Janet is the president. The businesses which the members of the communal bank run are varied, including making and selling sports clothing, selling jelly, gloves, and refreshments, making and selling sweaters, a local store, and baking and selling bread.

This loan will benefit small business owners such as Janet. She says that this is her third cycle with Pro Mujer, which she joined by the invitation of a friend who is a partner of the institution. She currently has a business selling handbags. She learned about this business from a friend, who sold these products in markets.

She will use this loan to increase her working capital by buying handbags, which she will acquire from wholesale vendors in the city of La Paz. She will then sell them as a street vendor in the markets in the city of El Alto. This type of work allows her to generate an income to maintain her household as much as possible, as she lives with her partner and has five children.
